text.__SUMMARY__: Rhododendron minus var. chapmanii (syn. Rhododendron chapmanii), also known as Chapman's rhododendron, is an evergreen shrub which is endemic to Florida.  It is an endangered species.
text.Description: Chapman's rhododendron grows to 2 metres tall and has an erect habit. New growth is red-brown, turning gray with age. The leaves are elliptic and are 3 to 6.5 cm long.  Pink flowers with 5 petals and 10 stamens appear in the spring (March to April in Florida).
text.Distribution:
There are three separate populations of the species within Florida, one in Clay County, the second in Gulf County and the third on the county line of Gadsden and Liberty counties.
